channel.title: Scientific American - Latest Issue
channel.description: Latest articles from Scientific American magazine

item.title: Ancient humans were making fire 350,000 years earlier than scientists realized
item.description: Making fire on demand was a milestone in the lives of our early ancestors. But the question of when that skill first arose has been difficult for scientists to pin down
item.dc:creator: Meghan Bartels
item.author: Meghan Bartels
item.guid: Ancient humans were making fire 350,000 years earlier than scientists realized

item.title: Math puzzle: The sum of all circles
item.description: Sum up the circles in this math puzzle
item.dc:creator: Jack Murtagh
item.author: Jack Murtagh
item.guid: Math puzzle: The sum of all circles

item.title: Yellowstone’s earthquakes spark microbial boom deep underground
item.description: Earthquake swarms can supercharge microbial growth
item.dc:creator: Damien Pine
item.author: Damien Pine
item.guid: Yellowstone’s earthquakes spark microbial boom deep underground

item.title: Astronomers spot one of the largest spinning structures in the universe
item.description: This enormous chain of hundreds of galaxies—a cosmic filament—is twisting through space 400 million light-years away
item.dc:creator: Humberto Basilio
item.author: Humberto Basilio
item.guid: Astronomers spot one of the largest spinning structures in the universe

item.title: AI tool decreased political polarization from social media algorithms
item.description: Researchers used a browser extension to reorder people’s X feeds, reducing their polarizing effect
item.dc:creator: Simon Makin
item.author: Simon Makin
item.guid: AI tool decreased political polarization from social media algorithms

item.title: Scientists create exotic new forms of ice never before seen on Earth
item.description: Ice has many forms beyond the mundane stuff produced in a standard freezer
item.dc:creator: Meghan Bartels
item.author: Meghan Bartels
item.guid: Scientists create exotic new forms of ice never before seen on Earth

item.title: Here’s how much practice you need to become the best in the world
item.description: Are you a specialist or a generalist? The answer could reveal something about how well you learn and perfect a skill
item.dc:creator: Claire Cameron
item.author: Claire Cameron
item.guid: Here’s how much practice you need to become the best in the world

item.title: Ancient bees burrowed inside bones, fossils reveal
item.description: Bones of now extinct species became a haven for bee babies thousands of years ago, scientists report in a first-of-its-kind discovery
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Pappas
item.author: Stephanie Pappas
item.guid: Ancient bees burrowed inside bones, fossils reveal

item.title: New research reveals how the brain separates speech into words
item.description: Speech blurs together unless you know the language; scientists found the brain signal that separates the words
item.dc:creator: Elise Cutts
item.author: Elise Cutts
item.guid: New research reveals how the brain separates speech into words

item.title: Axolotls can regenerate their thymus, a complex immune system organ
item.description: Axolotls can completely rebuild their thymus, a key immune organ
item.dc:creator: Taylor Mitchell Brown
item.author: Taylor Mitchell Brown
item.guid: Axolotls can regenerate their thymus, a complex immune system organ

item.title: How ‘effectively zero-knowledge’ proofs could transform cryptography
item.description: A new tool expands the ways people can prove they’ve solved a problem without revealing the solution
item.dc:creator: Peter Hall
item.author: Peter Hall
item.guid: How ‘effectively zero-knowledge’ proofs could transform cryptography

item.title: The ghost in the machine
item.description: AI is forcing us to redraw the line between author and tool
item.dc:creator: David M. Ewalt
item.author: David M. Ewalt
item.guid: The ghost in the machine

item.title: Readers respond to the November 2025 issue
item.description: Letters to the editors for the November 2025 issue of Scientific American
item.dc:creator: Aaron Shattuck
item.author: Aaron Shattuck
item.guid: Readers respond to the November 2025 issue

item.title: Vertical solar panels—wind-resistant trackers for high latitudes
item.description: Traditional solar fails in the windswept north. Two Swedish inventors are betting on aerodynamic resilience to solve the latitude gap
item.dc:creator: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.author: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.guid: Vertical solar panels—wind-resistant trackers for high latitudes

item.title: How Stanford doctors use AI scribes to cut paperwork and focus on patients
item.description: When a patient shared the story of her sister’s death, an AI captured the clinical details—freeing physician Christopher Sharp to just be present
item.dc:creator: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.author: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.guid: How Stanford doctors use AI scribes to cut paperwork and focus on patients

item.title: How artist Stephanie Dinkins is trying to fix AI bias
item.description: Transdisciplinary artist Stephanie Dinkins challenges us to rethink what we feed our machines—and asks what AI might become if it were trained on care
item.dc:creator: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.author: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.guid: How artist Stephanie Dinkins is trying to fix AI bias

item.title: A veteran teacher explains how to use AI in the classroom the right way
item.description: Veteran teacher Jen Roberts explains why generative tools are more than just a platform for cheating—they’re a way to make classrooms fairer and more human
item.dc:creator: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.author: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.guid: A veteran teacher explains how to use AI in the classroom the right way

item.title: How AI helps this civil rights lawyer beat the Feds
item.description: Joseph McMullen uses AI to sort through terabytes of evidence, freeing him to focus on what the machines can’t find: the human story
item.dc:creator: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.author: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.guid: How AI helps this civil rights lawyer beat the Feds

item.title: How one chemist is using AI and robots to automate lab experiments
item.description: Gabriel Gomes built an agent that turns plain English into physical experiments, enabling research that humans alone could never sustain
item.dc:creator: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.author: Deni Ellis Béchard
item.guid: How one chemist is using AI and robots to automate lab experiments

item.title: How influential people map their social world
item.description: The same brain areas that help us map physical space help us chart social connections, and the best relationship cartographers have most clout
item.dc:creator: Oriel FeldmanHall
item.author: Oriel FeldmanHall
item.guid: How influential people map their social world

item.title: Science crossword: What’s inside?
item.description: Play this crossword inspired by the March 2026 issue of Scientific American
item.dc:creator: Aimee Lucido
item.author: Aimee Lucido
item.guid: Science crossword: What’s inside?

item.title: This mathematician proved the random walk theorem to clear his name as a lurker
item.description: George Pólya’s random walk theorem absolved him of being a lurker and revealed how the laws of chance interact with physical space
item.dc:creator: Jack Murtagh
item.author: Jack Murtagh
item.guid: This mathematician proved the random walk theorem to clear his name as a lurker

item.title: Is a river alive? A conversation with Robert Macfarlane on nature’s sovereignty
item.description: Scientific American sits down with nature writer Robert Macfarlane to discuss his latest book—one of our top picks of 2025—and whether a river has rights
item.dc:creator: Andrea Gawrylewski
item.author: Andrea Gawrylewski
item.guid: Is a river alive? A conversation with Robert Macfarlane on nature’s sovereignty

item.title: Dealing with stress-caused sickness in family caregivers
item.description: People who help sick, aging loved ones are at risk for physical illness themselves. There may be ways to improve their resilience
item.dc:creator: Lydia Denworth
item.author: Lydia Denworth
item.guid: Dealing with stress-caused sickness in family caregivers

item.title: Poem: ‘Boulders at Hickory Run’
item.description: Science in meter and verse
item.dc:creator: Chris Bullard
item.author: Chris Bullard
item.guid: Poem: ‘Boulders at Hickory Run’

item.title: Cosmic magnification is one of the universe’s weirdest optical illusions
item.description: In our topsy-turvy universe, sometimes the farther away an object is, the bigger it seems to be
item.dc:creator: Phil Plait
item.author: Phil Plait
item.guid: Cosmic magnification is one of the universe’s weirdest optical illusions

item.title: Moving to a walkable city can add 1,100 steps to your day
item.description: Researchers found that walkable city design—not personal motivation—was the key factor behind people taking 1,100 more steps per day
item.dc:creator: Eve Lu
item.author: Eve Lu
item.guid: Moving to a walkable city can add 1,100 steps to your day

item.title: March 2026: Science history from 50, 100 and 150 years ago
item.description: A Greenland mystery; booming dunes
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Bryner
item.author: Jeanna Bryner
item.guid: March 2026: Science history from 50, 100 and 150 years ago

item.title: How AI copilots became everyday infrastructure
item.description: From the exam room to the classroom, artificial intelligence is no longer just a tool—it's infrastructure. An introduction to our special report on life in the age of AI.
item.dc:creator: Eric Sullivan
item.author: Eric Sullivan
item.guid: How AI copilots became everyday infrastructure

item.title: AI Is entering health care, and nurses are being asked to trust it
item.description: When alerts misfire or can’t explain themselves, nurses still carry the risk
item.dc:creator: Hilke Schellmann
item.author: Hilke Schellmann
item.guid: AI Is entering health care, and nurses are being asked to trust it

item.title: Deepfakes are getting faster than fact-checks, says digital forensics expert Hany Farid
item.description: Digital forensics pioneer Hany Farid explains what it will take to rebuild trust in the deepfake era
item.dc:creator: Eric Sullivan
item.author: Eric Sullivan
item.guid: Deepfakes are getting faster than fact-checks, says digital forensics expert Hany Farid

item.title: What are JWST’s Little Red Dots? Astronomers may finally have an answer
item.description: Astronomers are racing to understand mysterious ancient objects that pepper James Webb Space Telescope images
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Boyle
item.author: Rebecca Boyle
item.guid: What are JWST’s Little Red Dots? Astronomers may finally have an answer

item.title: Polyamory isn’t all about sex
item.description: An anthropologist’s detailed research shows polyamorists focus on intimacy and honesty, not sleeping around
item.dc:creator: Rebecca J. Lester
item.author: Rebecca J. Lester
item.guid: Polyamory isn’t all about sex

item.title: Photographer finds thousands of Triassic dinosaur prints on sheer mountain cliffs
item.description: A newfound site in the Italian Alps holds one of the largest collections of Triassic dinosaur footprints ever seen
item.dc:creator: Humberto Basilio
item.author: Humberto Basilio
item.guid: Photographer finds thousands of Triassic dinosaur prints on sheer mountain cliffs

item.title: Strange special relativity effect observed for the first time
item.description: Physicists have observed the bizarre Terrell-Penrose effect in real life
item.dc:creator: Victoria Helm
item.author: Victoria Helm
item.guid: Strange special relativity effect observed for the first time

item.title: Why privatizing public land won’t solve the housing crisis
item.description: An environmental scientist’s analysis reveals who will win and who will lose in the push to put federal land into private hands
item.dc:creator: Kyle Manley
item.author: Kyle Manley
item.guid: Why privatizing public land won’t solve the housing crisis
